titleStmt.title: Exceeding joyfull newes from Coventry declaring the happy successe of Col. Hambden, Col. Goodwyn, and the citisens of Coventry, against Prince Robert and his forces, who besieged Coventry on Friday last. With the number of them that were slain, and the taking of Cap. Iohnson and many other prisoners. Also the victorious proceedings of the Earle of Argile against the Earl of Derbie, who while the E. of Derby besieged Manchester the second time, and was from thence repulsed, seized upon the Ile of Man, the ancient inheritance of the Earls of Derby, and hath there placed many strong garrisons. With exceeding good news from Holland, expressed in the fidelity of the States to the Parliament of England, who made stay of four great vessels laden with men and ammunition to assist the King against the Parliament.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Exceeding joyfull newes from Coventry declaring the happy successe of Col. Hambden, Col. Goodwyn, and the citisens of Coventry, against Prince Robert and his forces, who besieged Coventry on Friday last. With the number of them that were slain, and the taking of Cap. Iohnson and many other prisoners. Also the victorious proceedings of the Earle of Argile against the Earl of Derbie, who while the E. of Derby besieged Manchester the second time, and was from thence repulsed, seized upon the Ile of Man, the ancient inheritance of the Earls of Derby, and hath there placed many strong garrisons. With exceeding good news from Holland, expressed in the fidelity of the States to the Parliament of England, who made stay of four great vessels laden with men and ammunition to assist the King against the Parliament.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Exceeding Joyfull NEWES FROM COVENTRY Declaring the happy Succe≈ø≈øe of Col. Hambden, Col. Goodwyn, and the Citi≈øens of Coventry, again≈øt Prince Robert and his forces, who be≈øieged Coventry on Friday-la≈øt. With the number of them that were ≈ølain, and the taking of Cap. Iohn≈øon and many other pri≈øoners.

Al≈øo the victorious Proceedings of the Earle of Argile again≈øt the Earl of Derbie, who while the E. of Derby be≈øieged Manche≈øter the ≈øecond time, and was from thence repul≈øed, ≈øeized upon the Ile of Man, the antient Inheritance of the Earls of Derby, and hath there placed many ≈øtrong Garri≈øons.

With exceeding good News from Holland, expre≈ø≈øed in the fidelity of the States to the Parliament of England, who made ≈øtay of four great Ve≈ø≈øels laden with men and Ammunition to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the King again≈øt the Parliament.
Printed for Richard We≈øt, October 19, 1642.

div.head: Exceeding Joyfull Newes from Wor≈øter.
div.p: SInce Prince Robert had tho≈øe mo≈øt happy Defeats given to him at Wor≈øter and Ludlow, wherein the malignant party for a ≈øea≈øon ≈øomething weakned, he hath ≈øince marched and lay with his forces within two miles of Burmegum, with a Re≈øolution to make a ≈øecond attempt upon the City of Coventry.

And upon Tue≈øday la≈øt he advanced his Forces, and upon Friday notwith≈øtanding the violence of the weather, his Forces l ‚Ä¢ y before the City, but according to the old Proverbe, He that is fore-warned, is forearmed.
The Citi≈øens of Corentry having intelligence of his determination, did ≈øo ≈øtrengthen and prepared them≈øelves for „Äà‚óä„Äâ comming, that his attempts will be fru≈øtrated:
For be≈øides other provi≈øion which was abundant, and ≈øtrong they had planted 26 pieces of Ordnance, with which they could play upon his forces which way ≈øoever he ≈øhould a≈ø≈øault them.

Upon Satterday according to his Re≈øolution he made an attempt upon the City but he found oppo≈øition to be beyond expectation, and all his A≈ø≈øaults and On≈øets were in vain and he not only was repul≈øed from his purpo≈øe, but with a great lo≈ø≈øe and much hurt done to his forces he was con≈øtrained to retreat.
For the Citi≈øens of Coventry be≈øides the help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Inhabitants round about them were a≈ø≈øi≈øted with other power and Forces.

For Collonell Hambden and Collonell Goodwyn, and ≈øome other Troopes which lay near Banbury ≈øide came in, and ≈øo violently ≈øet upon the Cavaleirs, that with a great lo≈ø≈øe they gave of their attempt, their were very many of them ≈ølain, ≈øome taken pri≈øoners.

The Number of them that were ≈ølain is
not certainly known, for they buried them in the place where they fell, and among many others one Captain John≈øon was taken pri≈øoner, a man very active in the pr ‚Ä¢
motion of this their cau≈øe.
The ≈øaid Captain is now in the Goal at Coventry, and with the re≈øt that were taken pri≈øoners with him will be ≈øent up to London, ≈øo ≈øoon as tho≈øe places are ≈øecured from the Cavaleers.

The Earl of Derby hath lately made a ≈øecond a≈ø≈øault upon Manche≈øter, but with as much di≈øcredit, and as ≈ømall ≈øucce≈ø≈øe as his fir≈øt was. For he was beaten back with great lo≈ø≈øe and hazard of him≈øelfe, and although he e≈øcaped with life, yet that was al≈øo in great hazard, for he was ≈øhot in the ≈øhoulder from the Town, and with much difficulty he got away, while the Earl did bu≈øie him≈øelf in tho≈øe tumultuous ways abroad, he little dreamed how his owne e≈øtate lay at ≈øtake at home, neither did hee conceive the lea≈øt fu≈øpition of any forrein enemy, but delighting him≈øelf with the publique di≈øtractions, he neglected his own e≈øtate.

For while he did mole≈øt the Countries of Che≈øter, and Lanca≈øter, the Earl of Argile a man full of con≈øcience and valour wit ‚Ä¢ ten thou≈øand men did be≈øiege the Ile o ‚Ä¢
Man, which is the Inheritance belonging to the Earls of Derby, and the ≈øiege was neither tedious nor dangerous.
For he got the Iland almo≈øt without any oppo≈øition, and hath there placed in divers places very ≈øtrong Garri≈øons.
He hath expelled the Country of all tho≈øe who≈øe integrity he doth ≈øu≈øpect, and whom he doth not find to be for the King and Parliament.

He hath enriched him≈øelf with great ≈øtore of trea≈øure, and other nece≈ø≈øary provi≈øion for War, which the Earls Father, and he that now is Earl had laid up there, this Earl intending that if his purpo≈øes ≈øhould not take effect, that then he would fly into the Iland, and with that provi≈øion that he had ≈øent thither, and was there trea≈øured up, and with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Inhabitants of the Iland, of who≈øe faith and con≈øtancie he ≈øeemed to be confident, to defend
and ≈øecure him≈øelf from any power that ≈øhould pur≈øue him, and that he was re≈øolved there to ≈øtand upon his guard.
But this his de≈øign is fru≈øtrate, for he is not like to regain it again, by rea≈øon that the Earl of Argile hath placed ≈øuch ≈øtrong Forces there.
There were lately in Holland, by meanes of the Queen 4. great Ve≈ø≈øels provided, rig'd and laden with great ≈øtore of Ammunition and Arms.

But the States according to their formerly promi≈øed fidelity did make ≈øtay of the ≈øhipping and all the re≈øt of the provi≈øion, and cau≈øed the ≈øhips to be unladen, and have al≈øo taken ≈øuch order, that if any Commanders what≈øoever who are imployed in the ≈øervice of the States, under the Command of the Prince of Orange, ≈øhall at any time come away, and leave their pre≈øent ≈øervice to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the King again≈øt his Parliament, that they ≈øhall for ever be ca≈øheerd of their places, and be made uncapable hereafter of the ≈øame office and place again.

And they did al≈øo by a Me≈ø≈øage ≈øent to the Hou≈øe, intimate their good affection which they bear to the Parliament, and although there hath bin very many plots and de≈øigns both there, and al≈øo in divers other places ≈øet on foot to promote the cau≈øe of the di≈øturbers of the peace and quiet df this Kingdome, yet that they hither have, and hereafter will, be vigilant to prevent all ≈øuch attempts what≈øoever, and that they will not admit as neer as po≈ø≈øibly they can, that any plot or con≈øpiracie what≈øoever ≈øhall take effect in tho≈øe Countryes, that might any wayes ≈øeeme prejudiciall to the pre≈øent Proceedings of the Parliament of England.
